HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 29, 1927

FIVE MEN ELECTED
TO TAU BETA -PI
Dr. W. B. Kouenhoven,
Alfred Banos, J Wallace
Joyce, Edward Skipper and
H. Ridgely Warfield were
elected to membership in
Tau Beta Pi honorary engineering fraternity last week.
The announcement of these
elections was made public
at the weekly assembly on
Thursday.
These men, with the exception of Dr. Kouenhoven,
who is a professor in the engineering school, are members of the junior class and
will be initiated at a banquet to be held by this organization tonight.
Tau
Beta Pi is an engineering
society which corresponds
to Phi Beta Kappa in academic circles.

AN INVITATION
Every year a more or less feeble cry goes up on the campus
for some medium through which literary effort on the part of
students can find expression. There is talk of a magazine, there
is a little enthusiasm, and there are discussions. First, it is decided that such a magazine could not be financed at Hopkins.
Then the less hopeful among the protagonists lose heart because
they become fearful about the available material on the campus.
Unfortunately, it seems that both objections are sorrowfully valid.
A half-hearted attempt was begun in the NEWS-LETTER when
the "Yes and No" column was inaugurated a few years ago. Contributions were solicited, but most that have been received have
been poor if not mediocre. Either there is little literary talent
on the campus or else it is inarticulate as far as the campus is
concerned.
The coming of spring has, however, made us optimistic. We
fully realize that it is true that there are no Bertrand Russells or
Anatole Frances or George Gordons among the undergraduates,
but it would be too awful a truth to face if there were no talent
whatsoever in Johns Hopkins. We believe that with active
encouragement, both from the faculty and from graduate students, writers of ability can be unearthed.
Our optimism has ripened into ambition. We believe that
although financial reasons preclude the possibility of a magazine
in the University, it is entirely feasible that a page in the NEWSLETTER can be devoted to this purpose every week or possibly
twice every week. We express our confidence with one qualification, however. In order for literary expression to be kept on
a high plane, the cooperation' of the faculty and students in the
graduate departments is indispensable for the volume of acceptable
weekly contributions from undergraduates alone would be too
small to justify any effort. Alumni contributions will also be
welcomed.
As we believe that this cooperation can be secured, we shall
attempt the experiment for the remainder of the semester. Every
Tuesday the -editoriarpage-of the NMS-LETTER will be devoted
to articles, stories, or poems by Hopkins people—faculty, graduates, undergraduates. We invite you to contribute—please try
to limit your wordiness to one thousand words, though we specify
no minimum.
We are conducting this experiment as a challenge. It has
often been said that Hopkins students cannot or will not support
a literary periodical; such an assertion can be disproved, and, we
hope will be.

USE

YES and NO
Just had a horrible thought. I was supposing, which is iii
itself a dangerous pastime, and among other suppositions, most
of them relevant to weather ;—whether or not I can cram everything in four short weeks, bad weather, Baltimore weather, and
whether to write this column now, or later, there appeared suddenly and without warning this monstrous hypothesis: suppose
the editor of this admirable journal should say, "Write something
of particular interest to the undergraduate body." Now isn't that
a pleasant thought for a peaceful mind on a spring morning? No.
What would it he? I have considered while regarding the
manner in which that first paragraph mars an otherwise spotless
sheet. Somebody once decided that it was even more pleasurable
to sully a clean sheet of white paper than to make foot-prints on
an unknown expanse of snow. Either is certainly an example
of the very human tendency to improve on perfection. Which has
nothing to do with the case.
It wouldn't be studies. Undergraduates are young ;—younger than their years, which makes them correspond to the average
kindergarten child, and the natural impulse of youth is to live.
Study produces books, of which the number is already far too
great. Think what a splendid blaze all the books in the world
would make. Our own library would produce quite a tidy little
bonfire, but what would the librarians do then, poor things? Why,
they'd fly to the Barn, to keep themselves ... All of which proves
the statement about kindergarten children.
To return to the subject. . . . What is the subject? Every
article, even in the NEWS-LETTER, should have a subject, every
paragraph should have a topic sentence, every sentence a subject
and a verb. That reminds me of English composition, whose
coming abolition I thoroughly abhor. It has always served as a
sort of Bromo-Seltzer for heads giddy with mistaken ideas about
the rah-rah college life which most freshmen bring along as a
prep-school heritage. Its effect was sobering, not to say. depressing. To enable them to write for the college paper, all entering
students assuredly need this course.
Would it he an article on a topic of current interest? I think
not. Sacco and Vanzetti did something, or if they didn't, they
might as well have, because they got burned anyway. That's all
1 know about it. Who knows any more? Speak up, O'Dunne.
Speaking of O'Dunne, I regret to note that he is slowing down.
There are only two hurrying seniors, and Arnold's rush is more
nervous than business-like; Gene always seems to be sharing the
worries of Dr. Goodnow, President Coolidge, and God Almighty.
Therefore, it was shocking and disappointing to see him seated,
outside of class.
Obviously, I have digressed. 'Digressions are peculiar things.
Far more natural to the human mind, I believe, than orderly
topic-sentence thinking. Conversations are almost entirely digression. Thousands of friendly arguments which originally concerned one definite question, have shifted gradually into ordinary
and rather catty gossip.
Gossip! That's it! The thing of particular interest to undergraduates. The boon of virtuous or hypocritical men, the dread
of sinners. Gossip about anything, from alcohol to. zoology. . . .
I will be contradicted, I hope. I've been contradicted once before,
ostensibly because I wrote something which wasn't true. That's
a peculiar cause for criticism. One never tells the truth when
the lie is more interesting. One never, even in the rare event that
he knows it, tells the truth about himself. But just allow the
bored young man to dig his teeth into a succulent morsel of scandalous truth about somebody else, and you have the thing "of
particular interest to undergraduates."
I cannot possibly expand this thought further, it was a very
limited subject anyway, and even without regarding these bounds
I have come to an impasse. if I had not just experienced a
wearisome and enervating quiz, I might concoct a rhyme, but that,
under the circumstances, is out of the question. However, anyone can write free-verse, and the attempt should be novel if unsuccessful.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 29, 1927

FIVE MEN ELECTED
TO TAU BETA -PI
Dr. W. B. Kouenhoven,
Alfred Banos, J Wallace
Joyce, Edward Skipper and
H. Ridgely Warfield were
elected to membership in
Tau Beta Pi honorary engineering fraternity last week.
The announcement of these
elections was made public
at the weekly assembly on
Thursday.
These men, with the exception of Dr. Kouenhoven,
who is a professor in the engineering school, are members of the junior class and
will be initiated at a banquet to be held by this organization tonight.
Tau
Beta Pi is an engineering
society which corresponds
to Phi Beta Kappa in academic circles.

AN INVITATION
Every year a more or less feeble cry goes up on the campus
for some medium through which literary effort on the part of
students can find expression. There is talk of a magazine, there
is a little enthusiasm, and there are discussions. First, it is decided that such a magazine could not be financed at Hopkins.
Then the less hopeful among the protagonists lose heart because
they become fearful about the available material on the campus.
Unfortunately, it seems that both objections are sorrowfully valid.
A half-hearted attempt was begun in the NEWS-LETTER when
the "Yes and No" column was inaugurated a few years ago. Contributions were solicited, but most that have been received have
been poor if not mediocre. Either there is little literary talent
on the campus or else it is inarticulate as far as the campus is
concerned.
The coming of spring has, however, made us optimistic. We
fully realize that it is true that there are no Bertrand Russells or
Anatole Frances or George Gordons among the undergraduates,
but it would be too awful a truth to face if there were no talent
whatsoever in Johns Hopkins. We believe that with active
encouragement, both from the faculty and from graduate students, writers of ability can be unearthed.
Our optimism has ripened into ambition. We believe that
although financial reasons preclude the possibility of a magazine
in the University, it is entirely feasible that a page in the NEWSLETTER can be devoted to this purpose every week or possibly
twice every week. We express our confidence with one qualification, however. In order for literary expression to be kept on
a high plane, the cooperation' of the faculty and students in the
graduate departments is indispensable for the volume of acceptable
weekly contributions from undergraduates alone would be too
small to justify any effort. Alumni contributions will also be
welcomed.
As we believe that this cooperation can be secured, we shall
attempt the experiment for the remainder of the semester. Every
Tuesday the -editoriarpage-of the NMS-LETTER will be devoted
to articles, stories, or poems by Hopkins people—faculty, graduates, undergraduates. We invite you to contribute—please try
to limit your wordiness to one thousand words, though we specify
no minimum.
We are conducting this experiment as a challenge. It has
often been said that Hopkins students cannot or will not support
a literary periodical; such an assertion can be disproved, and, we
hope will be.

USE

YES and NO
Just had a horrible thought. I was supposing, which is iii
itself a dangerous pastime, and among other suppositions, most
of them relevant to weather ;—whether or not I can cram everything in four short weeks, bad weather, Baltimore weather, and
whether to write this column now, or later, there appeared suddenly and without warning this monstrous hypothesis: suppose
the editor of this admirable journal should say, "Write something
of particular interest to the undergraduate body." Now isn't that
a pleasant thought for a peaceful mind on a spring morning? No.
What would it he? I have considered while regarding the
manner in which that first paragraph mars an otherwise spotless
sheet. Somebody once decided that it was even more pleasurable
to sully a clean sheet of white paper than to make foot-prints on
an unknown expanse of snow. Either is certainly an example
of the very human tendency to improve on perfection. Which has
nothing to do with the case.
It wouldn't be studies. Undergraduates are young ;—younger than their years, which makes them correspond to the average
kindergarten child, and the natural impulse of youth is to live.
Study produces books, of which the number is already far too
great. Think what a splendid blaze all the books in the world
would make. Our own library would produce quite a tidy little
bonfire, but what would the librarians do then, poor things? Why,
they'd fly to the Barn, to keep themselves ... All of which proves
the statement about kindergarten children.
To return to the subject. . . . What is the subject? Every
article, even in the NEWS-LETTER, should have a subject, every
paragraph should have a topic sentence, every sentence a subject
and a verb. That reminds me of English composition, whose
coming abolition I thoroughly abhor. It has always served as a
sort of Bromo-Seltzer for heads giddy with mistaken ideas about
the rah-rah college life which most freshmen bring along as a
prep-school heritage. Its effect was sobering, not to say. depressing. To enable them to write for the college paper, all entering
students assuredly need this course.
Would it he an article on a topic of current interest? I think
not. Sacco and Vanzetti did something, or if they didn't, they
might as well have, because they got burned anyway. That's all
1 know about it. Who knows any more? Speak up, O'Dunne.
Speaking of O'Dunne, I regret to note that he is slowing down.
There are only two hurrying seniors, and Arnold's rush is more
nervous than business-like; Gene always seems to be sharing the
worries of Dr. Goodnow, President Coolidge, and God Almighty.
Therefore, it was shocking and disappointing to see him seated,
outside of class.
Obviously, I have digressed. 'Digressions are peculiar things.
Far more natural to the human mind, I believe, than orderly
topic-sentence thinking. Conversations are almost entirely digression. Thousands of friendly arguments which originally concerned one definite question, have shifted gradually into ordinary
and rather catty gossip.
Gossip! That's it! The thing of particular interest to undergraduates. The boon of virtuous or hypocritical men, the dread
of sinners. Gossip about anything, from alcohol to. zoology. . . .
I will be contradicted, I hope. I've been contradicted once before,
ostensibly because I wrote something which wasn't true. That's
a peculiar cause for criticism. One never tells the truth when
the lie is more interesting. One never, even in the rare event that
he knows it, tells the truth about himself. But just allow the
bored young man to dig his teeth into a succulent morsel of scandalous truth about somebody else, and you have the thing "of
particular interest to undergraduates."
I cannot possibly expand this thought further, it was a very
limited subject anyway, and even without regarding these bounds
I have come to an impasse. if I had not just experienced a
wearisome and enervating quiz, I might concoct a rhyme, but that,
under the circumstances, is out of the question. However, anyone can write free-verse, and the attempt should be novel if unsuccessful.
